description.narrative: Promote equitable and sustainable development by contributing to a world free of the threats of armed violence and weapons.

UNICEF's "Prevent and Protect: Armed Violence and Weapons in Child Protection"-programme focuses on landmines and small and light weapons. The programme aims at reducing threats of armed violence, the spread of weapons and unexploded ordinances of war. This implementation includes strengthening national systems for protection of children and enhancing government's responsibilities.

Unicef har till Sida inkommit med en ansökan om stöd för åren 2014-2017. Stödet föreslås ges till Unicefs Child Protection Unit, Armed Violence and Weapons Team för implementering av globalt kapacitetsbyggande och påverkansarbete för minskat/förebyggande av väpnat våld (fokus på små och lätta vapen, SALW) samt hantering av minor. Stödet är tänkt att fördelas till Unicefs huvudkontor i New York, som därefter distribuerar stöd till regional och landnivå efter behov årligen. Påverkansarbetet koordineras och utförs av UNICEF på huvudkontorsnivå, emedan kapacitetsbyggandet och metodutvecklingen sker primärt regionalt och på landnivå. Syftet är att genom ett jämlikhetsperspektiv nå ut till de barn och unga som är mest utsatta för problematiken i fråga.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
16.4 - By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.
16.4 - Till 2030 avsevärt minska de olagliga finansiella flödena och vapenflödena, öka möjligheterna att återvinna och återfå stulna tillgångar samt bekämpa alla former av organiserad brottslighet.

description.narrative: The UNICEF implemented 'Prevent and Protect: Armed Violence and Weapons in Child Protection Programme' has two components; one focusing on preventing armed violence in Central America; and the other focusing on mine action globally. Sida’s support to the mine action component came to an end by the end of 2017 while the preventing armed violence component was extended until December 2018. Examples of results achieved 2015-2018: -At the global level UNICEF was one of the actors contributing to the finalisations of the International Small Arms Control Standards (ISACS). -At the regional level, up to 239,439 children and adolescents have benefited from the Armed Violence and Weapons Prevention (AVPR) interventions. -UNICEF has implemented various violence prevention activities targeting children and youth in Central America. Prevention activities in Honduras, for example, included supporting 22 municipalities (reaching more than 50,000 children) with information about protection from and prevention of different forms of violence. -The establishment of 245 studies, policies, laws or budgets where AVPR was integrated into the child protection perspective, and 44 reliable data sources of injury surveillance systems that include injuries from armed violence. This has further contributed to fuelling informed debate among civil society and policy makers around the consequences of armed violence on children and adolescents. In Honduras, discussions led to the approval of a new Law on Firearms that raises the legal age to bear arms to 21 years old. -In Jamaica, the rehabilitation of eleven safe community spaces supported over 1,000 children to heal and overcome the impact of traumatic violent events and build resilience. -Efforts to transform schools into protective spaces for children through the promotion of artistic, cultural and sport activities, to maximize school retention and promoting child friendly teaching, reached 4,580 children in El Salvador and 21,802 in Honduras. -In Jamaica, the AVPR Programme supported the Civil Society Organisation Peace Management Initiative (PMI)’s Violence Interrupters Programme that provides essential support to help young people transition away from violence. The effort led to an improvements in communication skills instead of acts of violence between rival gangs. -UNICEF has provided extensive training to law enforcement officers around the importance of respecting the rights of children and adolescents. In both Jamaica and Guatemala, the training has led to some behavioural changes among participating law enforcement officers. -Almost 6 million children received mine and explosive remnants of war education in 23 countries in 2017. 82 % of these children lives in Syria, Yemen and Iraq. -374 child victims of landmines and explosive remnants of war receive support in 9 countries.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
